chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called LSA Secrets. Their names are as follows:
* Password Policies 
* Privileged Account Management 
* User Training 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies are a mitigation method that involves setting and enforcing secure password policies for accounts to enhance security against attacks.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method that educates users to recognize access or manipulation attempts by adversaries, thereby reducing the risk of successful spearphishing and social engineering attacks.

entities.name: LSA SECRETS
entities.description: LSA Secrets is an attack technique that can be mitigated through various methods, including Password Policies, Privileged Account Management, and User Training.

chunk:
There are 5 software using the attack technique called XDG Autostart Entries. Their names are as follows:
* Pupy
* NETWIRE
* CrossRAT
* RotaJakiro
* Fysbis

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: NETWIRE
Software description: [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) that has been used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: McAfee Netwire Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye APT33 Webinar Sept 2017)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: CrossRAT
Software description: [CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235) is a cross platform RAT.
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Software name: RotaJakiro
Software description: [RotaJakiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1078) is a 64-bit Linux backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First seen in 2018, it uses a plugin architecture to extend capabilities. [RotaJakiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1078) can determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: RotaJakiro 2021 netlab360 analysis)(Citation: netlab360 rotajakiro vs oceanlotus)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Fysbis
Software description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) is a Linux-based backdoor used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) that dates back to at least 2014.(Citation: Fysbis Palo Alto Analysis)
Platforms: Linux

These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Pre-compromise
Mitigation method description: This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

entities.name: BOTNET
entities.description: Botnet is an attack technique that involves a network of compromised computers used to perform malicious tasks, often without the owners' knowledge.

entities.name: PRE-COMPROMISE
entities.description: Pre-compromise refers to mitigation methods that are applied before an adversary gains initial access to a system, focusing on reconnaissance and resource development techniques.

entities.name: INITIAL ACCESS
entities.description: Initial access refers to the first stage of a cyber attack where an adversary gains entry into a system or network.

entities.name: RECONNAISSANCE
entities.description: Reconnaissance is a phase in the attack lifecycle where attackers gather information about a target to identify vulnerabilities.

entities.name: RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT
entities.description: Resource development involves preparing and acquiring the necessary tools and capabilities to conduct an attack.

chunk: There are 10 software using the attack technique called Domain Account. Their names are as follows: * Net * CrackMapExec * dsquery * BloodHound * Empire * PoshC2 * SILENTTRINITY * Brute Ratel C4 * AdFind * SoreFang The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows: Software name: *** Software description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates. Software name: Net Software description: The [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) utility is a component of the Windows operating system. It is used in command-line operations for control of users, groups, services, and network connections. (Citation: Microsoft Net Utility) [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) has a great deal of functionality, (Citation: Savill 1999) much of which is useful for an adversary, such as gathering system and network information for Discovery, moving laterally through [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002) using net use commands, and interacting with services. The net1.exe utility is executed for certain functionality when net.exe is run and can be used directly in commands such as net1 user. Platforms: Windows Software name: CrackMapExec Software description: [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488), or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python and designed for penetration testing against networks. [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) collects Active Directory information to conduct lateral movement through targeted networks.(Citation: CME Github September 2018) Platforms: Windows Software name: dsquery Software description: [dsquery](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0105) is a command-line utility that can be used to query Active Directory for information from a system within a domain. (Citation: TechNet Dsquery) It is typically installed only on Windows Server versions but can be installed on non-server variants through the Microsoft-provided Remote Server Administration Tools bundle. Platforms: Windows Software name: BloodHound Software description: [BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521) is an Active Directory (AD) reconnaissance tool that can reveal hidden relationships and identify attack paths within an AD environment.(Citation: GitHub Bloodhound)(Citation: CrowdStrike BloodHound April 2018)(Citation: FoxIT Wocao December 2019) Platforms: Windows Software name: Empire Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire) Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows Software name: PoshC2 Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2) Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS Software name: SILENTTRINITY Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019) Platforms: Windows Software name: Brute Ratel C4 Software description: [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool that first appeared in December 2020. [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was specifically designed to avoid detection by endpoint detection and response (EDR) and antivirus (AV) capabilities, and deploys agents called badgers to enable arbitrary command execution for lateral movement, privilege escalation, and persistence. In September 2022, a cracked version of [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was leaked in the cybercriminal underground, leading to its use by threat actors.(Citation: Dark Vortex Brute Ratel C4)(Citation: Palo Alto Brute Ratel July

entities.name: NET
entities.description: Net is a command-line utility that is part of the Windows operating system, used for controlling users, groups, services, and network connections, and is often utilized by adversaries for various operations including gathering system information and lateral movement through networks.

entities.name: CRACKMAPEXEC
entities.description: CrackMapExec, or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python for penetration testing against networks, designed to collect Active Directory information and facilitate lateral movement.

entities.name: DSQUERY
entities.description: dsquery is a command-line utility used to query Active Directory for information from a system within a domain, typically installed on Windows Server versions.

entities.name: BLOODHOUND
entities.description:
BloodHound is an Active Directory reconnaissance tool that reveals hidden relationships and identifies attack paths within an Active Directory environment.
BloodHound is an Active Directory reconnaissance tool that can reveal hidden relationships and identify attack paths within an AD environment, aiding in security assessments and penetration testing.

entities.name: EMPIRE
entities.description: Empire is an open-source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework available on GitHub, primarily written in Python with post-exploitation agents in PowerShell and Python.

entities.name: POSHC2
entities.description: PoshC2 is an open-source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that focuses on Windows implantation but also includes components for Linux/macOS, primarily written in Python and PowerShell.

entities.name: SILENTTRINITY
entities.description: SILENTTRINITY is an open-source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python, used in cyber campaigns against government agencies.

entities.name: BRUTE RATEL C4
entities.description: Brute Ratel C4 is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool designed to avoid detection by security measures, enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

entities.name: AD FIND
entities.description: AdFind is a command-line tool used to query Active Directory for information, helping security professionals and adversaries alike to gather data about users and groups within a domain.

In September 2022, a cracked version of [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was leaked in the cybercriminal underground, leading to its use by threat actors.(Citation: Dark Vortex Brute Ratel C4)(Citation: Palo Alto Brute Ratel July 2022)(Citation: MDSec Brute Ratel August 2022)(Citation: SANS Brute Ratel October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Black Basta October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AdFind
Software description: [AdFind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0552) is a free command-line query tool that can be used for gathering information from Active Directory.(Citation: Red Canary Hospital Thwarted Ryuk October 2020)(Citation: FireEye FIN6 Apr 2019)(Citation: FireEye Ryuk and Trickbot January 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SoreFang
Software description: [SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) is first stage downloader used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) for exfiltration and to load other malware.(Citation: NCSC APT29 July 2020)(Citation: CISA SoreFang July 2016)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: SOREFANG
entities.description: SoreFang is a first stage downloader used by APT29 for exfiltration and loading other malware.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber threat group known for its sophisticated cyber espionage activities, including the use of SoreFang.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a platform on which various cybersecurity tools, including AdFind and SoreFang, operate.

chunk:
There are 6 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Network Device Configuration Dump. Their names are as follows:
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Network Segmentation 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Software Configuration 
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Update Software 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Update Software
Mitigation method description: Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

chunk:
There are 5 software using the attack technique called LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay. Their names are as follows:
* Impacket
* Empire
* PoshC2
* Pupy
* Responder

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Impacket
Software description: [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Responder
Software description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS and MDNS poisoning, with built-in HTTP/SMB/MSSQL/FTP/LDAP rogue authentication server supporting NTLMv1/NTLMv2/LMv2, Extended Security NTLMSSP and Basic HTTP authentication. (Citation: GitHub Responder)
Platforms: None

entities.description: Impacket is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols, containing tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.

entities.name: EMPIRE
entities.description: Empire is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework, primarily written in Python, with post-exploitation agents in PowerShell for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS.

entities.name: POSHC2
entities.description: PoshC2 is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework, with server-side components in Python and implants in PowerShell, primarily focused on Windows implantation but also supports Linux/macOS.

entities.name: PUPY
entities.description: Pupy is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation tool written in Python, capable of being generated as various payloads for multiple operating systems including Windows, Linux, OSX, and Android.

entities.name: RESPONDER
entities.description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS, and MDNS poisoning, featuring built-in rogue authentication servers for various protocols.

entities.name: SMB RELAY
entities.description: SMB Relay is an attack technique that allows an attacker to relay authentication requests to gain unauthorized access to network resources.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Bypass User Account Control. Their names are as follows:
* Update Software 
* Audit 
* User Account Control 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Update Software
Mitigation method description: Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: User Account Control
Mitigation method description: Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.description: Update Software is a mitigation method that involves performing regular software updates to reduce the risk of exploitation.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT CONTROL
entities.description: User Account Control is a mitigation method that configures Windows settings to prevent adversaries from obtaining elevated access.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the permissions and use of privileged accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to various strategies employed to reduce the risk of security vulnerabilities and attacks on systems.

chunk:
There are 5 software using the attack technique called Masquerade File Type. Their names are as follows:
* Brute Ratel C4
* QakBot
* ANDROMEDA
* AvosLocker
* OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Brute Ratel C4
Software description: [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool that first appeared in December 2020. [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was specifically designed to avoid detection by endpoint detection and response (EDR) and antivirus (AV) capabilities, and deploys agents called badgers to enable arbitrary command execution for lateral movement, privilege escalation, and persistence. In September 2022, a cracked version of [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was leaked in the cybercriminal underground, leading to its use by threat actors.(Citation: Dark Vortex Brute Ratel C4)(Citation: Palo Alto Brute Ratel July 2022)(Citation: MDSec Brute Ratel August 2022)(Citation: SANS Brute Ratel October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Black Basta October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ANDROMEDA
Software description: [ANDROMEDA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1074) is commodity malware that was widespread in the early 2010's and continues to be observed in infections across a wide variety of industries. During the 2022 [C0026](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0026) campaign, threat actors re-registered expired [ANDROMEDA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1074) C2 domains to spread malware to select targets in Ukraine.(Citation: Mandiant Suspected Turla Campaign February 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AvosLocker
Software description: [AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) is ransomware written in C++ that has been offered via the Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) model. It was first observed in June 2021 and has been used against financial services, critical manufacturing, government facilities, and other critical infrastructure sectors in the United States. As of March 2022, [AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) had also been used against organizations in Belgium, Canada, China, Germany, Saudi Arabia, Spain, Syria, Taiwan, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom.(Citation: Malwarebytes AvosLocker Jul 2021)(Citation: Trend Micro AvosLocker Apr 2022)(Citation: Joint CSA AvosLocker Mar 2022)
Platforms: Linux, Windows

Software name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Software description: [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) is a macOS backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First discovered in 2015, [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has continued to make improvements using a plugin architecture to extend capabilities, specifically using `.dylib` files. [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) can also determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: Unit42 OceanLotus 2017)(Citation: TrendMicro MacOS April 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro MacOS Backdoor November 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Mitigation method name: ***

These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Multi-factor Authentication
Mitigation method description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION
entities.description: Multi-factor Authentication is a security method that requires two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system, enhancing security by combining multiple forms of verification such as a username and password along with a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a security practice that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root accounts, to ensure proper access control and security.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation methods are strategies or techniques employed to reduce the risk or impact of security threats, specifically in the context of authentication and access control.

chunk:
There are 4 software using the attack technique called Cached Domain Credentials. Their names are as follows:
* Cachedump
* LaZagne
* Pupy
* Okrum

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Cachedump
Software description: [Cachedump](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0119) is a publicly-available tool that program extracts cached password hashes from a system’s registry. (Citation: Mandiant APT1)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LaZagne
Software description: [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system. It has modules for Windows, Linux, and OSX, but is mainly focused on Windows systems. [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub LaZagne Dec 2018)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Okrum
Software description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) is a Windows backdoor that has been seen in use since December 2016 with strong links to [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004).(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: LaZagne is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on various systems, mainly focused on Windows but also supports Linux and macOS.

entities.description: Okrum is a Windows backdoor that has been in use since December 2016, with strong links to the Ke3chang group.

* Privileged Process Integrity 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***

These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Process Integrity
Mitigation method description: Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED PROCESS INTEGRITY

Software name: LaZagne
Software description: [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system. It has modules for Windows, Linux, and OSX, but is mainly focused on Windows systems. [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub LaZagne Dec 2018)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

There are 10 software using the attack technique called Embedded Payloads. Their names are as follows:
* Invoke-PSImage
* DEADEYE
* BADHATCH
* Emotet
* macOS.OSAMiner
* Dtrack
* Netwalker
* SMOKEDHAM
* ComRAT
* Uroburos

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Invoke-PSImage
Software description: [Invoke-PSImage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0231) takes a PowerShell script and embeds the bytes of the script into the pixels of a PNG image. It generates a one liner for executing either from a file of from the web. Example of usage is embedding the PowerShell code from the Invoke-Mimikatz module and embed it into an image file. By calling the image file from a macro for example, the macro will download the picture and execute the PowerShell code, which in this case will dump the passwords. (Citation: GitHub Invoke-PSImage)
Platforms: None

Software name: DEADEYE
Software description: [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) is a malware launcher that has been used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) since at least May 2021. [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) has variants that can either embed a payload inside a compiled binary (DEADEYE.EMBED) or append it to the end of a file (DEADEYE.APPEND).(Citation: Mandiant APT41)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BADHATCH
Software description: [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) is a backdoor that has been utilized by [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) since at least 2019. [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) has been used to target the insurance, retail, technology, and chemical industries in the United States, Canada, South Africa, Panama, and Italy.(Citation: Gigamon BADHATCH Jul 2019)(Citation: BitDefender BADHATCH Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is a modular malware variant which is primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) and [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: macOS.OSAMiner
Software description: [macOS.OSAMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1048) is a Monero mining trojan that was first observed in 2018; security researchers assessed [macOS.OSAMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1048) may have been circulating since at least 2015. [macOS.OSAMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1048) is known for embedding one run-only AppleScript into another, which helped the malware evade full analysis for five years due to a lack of Apple event (AEVT) analysis tools.(Citation: SentinelLabs reversing run-only applescripts 2021)(Citation: VMRay OSAMiner dynamic analysis 2021)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Dtrack
Software description: [Dtrack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0567) is spyware that was discovered in 2019 and has been used against Indian financial institutions, research facilities, and the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant. [Dtrack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0567) shares similarities with the DarkSeoul campaign, which was attributed to [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). (Citation: Kaspersky Dtrack)(Citation: Securelist Dtrack)(Citation: Dragos WASSONITE)(Citation: CyberBit Dtrack)(Citation: ZDNet Dtrack)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Netwalker
Software description: [Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457) is fileless ransomware written in PowerShell and executed directly in memory.(Citation: TrendMicro Netwalker May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SMOKEDHAM
Software description: [SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) is a Powershell-based .NET backdoor that was first reported in May 2021; it has been used by at least one ransomware-as-a-service affiliate.(Citation: FireEye Shining A Light on DARKSIDE May 2021)(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ComRAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone

RAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Uroburos
Software description: [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool written in C that has been used by units within Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolset to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and can easily incorporate new or replacement components.(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Mitigation method name: Pre-compromise
Mitigation method description: This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

entities.name: PRE-COMPROMISE
entities.description: Pre-compromise is a mitigation method that applies to activities before an adversary gains initial access, focusing on reconnaissance and resource development techniques.

There are 6 software using the attack technique called Keychain. Their names are as follows:
* LaZagne
* Green Lambert
* Proton
* MacMa
* Calisto
* iKitten

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: LaZagne
Software description: [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system. It has modules for Windows, Linux, and OSX, but is mainly focused on Windows systems. [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub LaZagne Dec 2018)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Green Lambert
Software description: [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) is a modular backdoor that security researchers assess has been used by an advanced threat group referred to as Longhorn and The Lamberts. First reported in 2017, the Windows variant of [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) may have been used as early as 2008; a macOS version was uploaded to a multiscanner service in September 2014.(Citation: Kaspersky Lamberts Toolkit April 2017)(Citation: Objective See Green Lambert for OSX Oct 2021)  
Platforms: Windows, iOS, macOS, Linux

Software name: Proton
Software description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) is a macOS backdoor focusing on data theft and credential access  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: MacMa
Software description: [MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) is a macOS-based backdoor with a large set of functionalities to control and exfiltrate files from a compromised computer. [MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) has been observed in the wild since November 2021.(Citation: ESET DazzleSpy Jan 2022)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Calisto
Software description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is a macOS Trojan that opens a backdoor on the compromised machine. [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is believed to have first been developed in 2016. (Citation: Securelist Calisto July 2018) (Citation: Symantec Calisto July 2018)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: iKitten
Software description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) is a macOS exfiltration agent  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

There are 6 software using the attack technique called Systemd Service. Their names are as follows:
* Pupy
* Fysbis
* RotaJakiro
* SysUpdate
* Exaramel for Linux
* Hildegard

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Fysbis
Software description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) is a Linux-based backdoor used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) that dates back to at least 2014.(Citation: Fysbis Palo Alto Analysis)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: RotaJakiro
Software description: [RotaJakiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1078) is a 64-bit Linux backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First seen in 2018, it uses a plugin architecture to extend capabilities. [RotaJakiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1078) can determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: RotaJakiro 2021 netlab360 analysis)(Citation: netlab360 rotajakiro vs oceanlotus)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: Exaramel for Linux
Software description: [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) is a backdoor written in the Go Programming Language and compiled as a 64-bit ELF binary. The Windows version is tracked separately under [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343).(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Hildegard
Software description: [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations. The malware was first observed in January 2021. The TeamTNT activity group is believed to be behind [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601). (Citation: Unit 42 Hildegard Malware)
Platforms: Linux, Containers, IaaS

entities.description: Pupy is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation tool written in Python, available on GitHub, and can be generated in various formats including Windows exe and Linux elf.

entities.name: FYSBIS
entities.description: Fysbis is a Linux-based backdoor used by APT28, dating back to at least 2014.

entities.name: ROTAJAKIRO
entities.description: RotaJakiro is a 64-bit Linux backdoor used by APT32, first seen in 2018, utilizing a plugin architecture for extended capabilities.

entities.name: SYSUPDATE
entities.description: SysUpdate is a backdoor written in C++ used by Threat Group-3390 since at least 2020.

entities.name: EXARAMEL FOR LINUX
entities.description: Exaramel for Linux is a backdoor written in Go, compiled as a 64-bit ELF binary, with a separate Windows version.

entities.name: HILDEGARD
entities.description: Hildegard is malware targeting misconfigured kubelets for access and cryptocurrency mining, first observed in January 2021, linked to the TeamTNT group.

entities.name: APT32
entities.description: APT32 is a cyber espionage group that has been linked to the development and use of RotaJakiro since its first appearance in 2018.

entities.name: THREAT GROUP-3390
entities.description: Threat Group-3390 is a cyber threat actor known for using SysUpdate in their operations since at least 2020.

entities.name: TEAMTNT
entities.description: TeamTNT is a cybercriminal group believed to be behind the Hildegard malware, which targets misconfigured kubelets for cryptocurrency mining.

There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Shared Modules. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Shared Modules
Attack technique description: Adversaries may execute malicious payloads via loading shared modules. Shared modules are executable files that are loaded into processes to provide access to reusable code, such as specific custom functions or invoking OS API functions (i.e., [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106)).

Adversaries may use this functionality as a way to execute arbitrary payloads on a victim system. For example, adversaries can modularize functionality of their malware into shared objects that perform various functions such as managing C2 network communications or execution of specific actions on objective.

The Linux & macOS module loader can load and execute shared objects from arbitrary local paths. This functionality resides in `dlfcn.h` in functions such as `dlopen` and `dlsym`. Although macOS can execute `.so` files, common practice uses `.dylib` files.(Citation: Apple Dev Dynamic Libraries)(Citation: Linux Shared Libraries)(Citation: RotaJakiro 2021 netlab360 analysis)(Citation: Unit42 OceanLotus 2017)

The Windows module loader can be instructed to load DLLs from arbitrary local paths and arbitrary Universal Naming Convention (UNC) network paths. This functionality resides in `NTDLL.dll` and is part of the Windows [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) which is called from functions like `LoadLibrary` at run time.(Citation: Microsoft DLL)
Platforms: Windows, macOS, Linux

entities.name: SHARED MODULES
entities.description: Shared Modules is an attack technique where adversaries execute malicious payloads by loading shared modules, which are executable files that provide access to reusable code and can be used to execute arbitrary payloads on a victim system.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that can load DLLs from arbitrary local paths and UNC network paths as part of the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can execute shared objects and is involved in the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that can load and execute shared objects, playing a role in the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: MALICIOUS PAYLOADS
entities.description: Malicious payloads are harmful software components that adversaries execute on victim systems, often using techniques like Shared Modules.

entities.name: C2 NETWORK COMMUNICATIONS
entities.description: C2 network communications refer to the command and control communications that adversaries manage through shared modules in their malware.

entities.name: EXECUTION OF SPECIFIC ACTIONS
entities.description: Execution of specific actions refers to the targeted operations that adversaries can perform on a victim system using shared modules.

entities.name: DLLS
entities.description: DLLs (Dynamic Link Libraries) are files used by Windows that can be loaded by the module loader as part of the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: SHARED OBJECTS
entities.description: Shared objects are executable files used in Linux and macOS that can be loaded to execute code, relevant to the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: NATIVE API
entities.description: Native API refers to the set of functions provided by the operating system that can be used to load shared modules and execute payloads.

entities.name: DLFCN.H
entities.description: dlfcn.h is a header file in Linux that contains functions like dlopen and dlsym, which are used to load shared objects.

entities.name: NTDLL.DLL
entities.description: NTDLL.dll is a Windows system file that contains functions for loading DLLs, relevant to the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: LOADLIBRARY
entities.description: LoadLibrary is a function in Windows that is called at runtime to load DLLs, part of the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: CITATION: APPLE DEV DYNAMIC LIBRARIES
entities.description: A reference to documentation regarding dynamic libraries in macOS, relevant to the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: CITATION: LINUX SHARED LIBRARIES
entities.description: A reference to documentation regarding shared libraries in Linux, relevant to the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: CITATION: ROTA JAKIRO 2021 NETLAB360 ANALYSIS
entities.description: A reference to an analysis that discusses the Shared Modules attack technique.

entities.name: CITATION: UNIT42 OCEANLOTUS 2017
entities.description: A reference to a report that discusses the use of Shared Modules in the OceanLotus attack.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Sudo and Sudo Caching. Their names are as follows:
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Operating System Configuration 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: SUDO
entities.description: Sudo is an attack technique that allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user, as specified by the security policy.

entities.name: SUDO CACHING
entities.description: Sudo Caching is a technique that allows a user to execute commands without re-entering their password for a specified period of time, which can be exploited in attacks.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description:
Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a specific mitigation method aimed at limiting access to files and directories to enhance security.
A mitigation method that restricts access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description:
A mitigation method that involves making configuration changes related to the operating system to enhance security against attack techniques.
Operating System Configuration is a specific mitigation method that involves making changes to the operating system to improve security against attacks.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description:
Privileged Account Management is a specific mitigation method focused on controlling access and permissions for privileged accounts to prevent unauthorized actions.
A mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

* CSPY Downloader
* IronNetInjector
* PowerSploit
* MCMD
* Empire
* schtasks
* QuasarRAT
* Koadic
* AsyncRAT
* GoldMax

Software name: ***
Software description: ***

These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: CSPY Downloader
Software description: [CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527) is a tool designed to evade analysis and download additional payloads used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094).(Citation: Cybereason Kimsuky November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: IronNetInjector
Software description: [IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) is a [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolchain that utilizes scripts from the open-source IronPython implementation of Python with a .NET injector to drop one or more payloads including [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126).(Citation: Unit 42 IronNetInjector February 2021 )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MCMD
Software description: [MCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0500) is a remote access tool that provides remote command shell capability used by [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074).(Citation: Secureworks MCMD July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: schtasks
Software description: [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) is used to schedule execution of programs or scripts on a Windows system to run at a specific date and time. (Citation: TechNet Schtasks)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AsyncRAT
Software description: [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087) is an open-source remote access tool originally available through the NYANxCAT Github repository that has been used in malicious campaigns.(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Cisco Operation Layover September 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GoldMax
Software description: [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) is a second-stage C2 backdoor written in Go with Windows and Linux variants that are nearly identical in functionality. [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) was discovered in early 2021 during the investigation into the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), and has likely been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least mid-2019. [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) uses multiple defense evasion techniques, including avoiding virtualization execution and masking malicious traffic.(Citation: MSTIC NO

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Email Forwarding Rule. Their names are as follows:
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Audit 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: EMAIL FORWARDING RULE
entities.description: Email Forwarding Rule is an attack technique that can be mitigated through various methods to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: This mitigation method involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: This mitigation method involves protecting sensitive information with strong encryption to ensure its confidentiality and integrity.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: This mitigation method involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

chunk:
There are 3 software using the attack technique called Login Items. Their names are as follows:
* Green Lambert
* NETWIRE
* Dok

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Green Lambert
Software description: [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) is a modular backdoor that security researchers assess has been used by an advanced threat group referred to as Longhorn and The Lamberts. First reported in 2017, the Windows variant of [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) may have been used as early as 2008; a macOS version was uploaded to a multiscanner service in September 2014.(Citation: Kaspersky Lamberts Toolkit April 2017)(Citation: Objective See Green Lambert for OSX Oct 2021)  
Platforms: Windows, iOS, macOS, Linux

Software name: NETWIRE
Software description: [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) that has been used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: McAfee Netwire Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye APT33 Webinar Sept 2017)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Dok
Software description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that is able to collect user credentials and install a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic (i.e. [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557)).(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)(Citation: hexed osx.dok analysis 2019)(Citation: CheckPoint Dok)
Platforms: macOS

entities.description: Green Lambert is a modular backdoor software used by an advanced threat group known as Longhorn and The Lamberts, first reported in 2017, with a Windows variant possibly used since 2008 and a macOS version uploaded in 2014.

entities.name: NETWIRE
entities.description: NETWIRE is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.

entities.name: DOK
entities.description: Dok is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that collects user credentials and installs a malicious proxy server to redirect network traffic.

entities.name: CRIMINAL GROUPS
entities.description: Criminal groups are entities that have utilized NETWIRE for malicious activities since at least 2012.

entities.name: USER CREDENTIALS
entities.description: User credentials are sensitive information targeted by Dok for collection through its malicious activities.)<|COMPLETE|>

entities.name: THE LAMBERTS
entities.description: The Lamberts is an advanced threat group associated with the use of Green Lambert software.

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Hidden Window. Their names are as follows:
* Execution Prevention 
* Limit Software Installation 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a mitigation method that blocks users or groups from installing unapproved software.

Mitigation method name: Pre-compromise
Mitigation method description: This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

entities.name: PRE-COMPROMISE
entities.description: Pre-compromise is a mitigation method that applies to activities before an adversary gains initial access, focusing on reconnaissance and resource development techniques.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation methods are strategies or techniques used to reduce the risk or impact of cyber attack techniques.

entities.name: INITIAL ACCESS
entities.description: Initial Access refers to the stage in a cyber attack where an adversary gains entry into a target system or network.

entities.name: RECONNAISSANCE
entities.description: Reconnaissance is a phase in cyber attacks where attackers gather information about their target to identify vulnerabilities.

entities.name: RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT
entities.description: Resource Development involves preparing and acquiring the necessary tools and information to conduct a cyber attack.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management

Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

[QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Imminent Monitor
Software description: [Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434) was a commodity remote access tool (RAT) offered for sale from 2012 until 2019, when an operation was conducted to take down the Imminent Monitor infrastructure. Various cracked versions and variations of this RAT are still in circulation.(Citation: Imminent Unit42 Dec2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Clambling
Software description: [Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) is a modular backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2017.(Citation: Trend Micro DRBControl February 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WastedLocker
Software description: [WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) is a ransomware family attributed to [Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119) that has been used since at least May 2020. [WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) has been used against a broad variety of sectors, including manufacturing, information technology, and media.(Citation: Symantec WastedLocker June 2020)(Citation: NCC Group WastedLocker June 2020)(Citation: Sentinel Labs WastedLocker July 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PlugX
Software description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) is a remote access tool (RAT) with modular plugins that has been used by multiple threat groups.(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Fox Part 2)(Citation: New DragonOK)(Citation: Dell TG-3390)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CoinTicker
Software description: [CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) is a malicious application that poses as a cryptocurrency price ticker and installs components of the open source backdoors EvilOSX and EggShell.(Citation: CoinTicker 2019)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: PoetRAT
Software description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that was first identified in April 2020. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has been used in multiple campaigns against the private and public sectors in Azerbaijan, including ICS and SCADA systems in the energy sector. The STIBNITE activity group has been observed using the malware. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) derived its name from references in the code to poet William Shakespeare. (Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)(Citation: Talos PoetRAT October 2020)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software description: [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) is a family of downloaders initially discovered in 2018 embedded within trojanized cryptocurrency applications. [

Platforms: Windows

Software name: AppleJeus
Software description: [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) is a family of downloaders initially discovered in 2018 embedded within trojanized cryptocurrency applications. [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032), targeting companies in the energy, finance, government, industry, technology, and telecommunications sectors, and several countries including the United States, United Kingdom, South Korea, Australia, Brazil, New Zealand, and Russia. [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has been used to distribute the [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) RAT.(Citation: CISA AppleJeus Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

chunk:
There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Shared Modules. Their names are as follows:
* Execution Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks the execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

* Emotet

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is a modular malware variant which is primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) and [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a modular malware variant primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as TrickBot and IcedID, targeting the banking sector since June 2014.

entities.name: ICEDID

* Execution Prevention 
* Code Signing

Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.name: CODE SIGNING
entities.description: Code Signing is a mitigation method that enforces binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.name: LC_LOAD_DYLIB ADDITION
entities.description: LC_LOAD_DYLIB Addition is an attack technique that involves manipulating dynamic libraries in a system to execute malicious code.

entities.description: Multi-factor Authentication is a security method that requires two or more verification factors to gain access to a system, enhancing account security.

chunk:
There are 4 software using the attack technique called Hidden File System. Their names are as follows:
* ComRAT
* Regin
* BOOTRASH
* Uroburos

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: ComRAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Regin
Software description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) is a malware platform that has targeted victims in a range of industries, including telecom, government, and financial institutions. Some [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) timestamps date back to 2003. (Citation: Kaspersky Regin)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BOOTRASH
Software description: [BOOTRASH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0114) is a [Bootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/003) that targets Windows operating systems. It has been used by threat actors that target the financial sector.(Citation: Mandiant M Trends 2016)(Citation: FireEye Bootkits)(Citation: FireEye BOOTRASH SANS)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Uroburos
Software description: [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool written in C that has been used by units within Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolset to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and can easily incorporate new or replacement components.(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

entities.name: COMRAT
entities.description: ComRAT is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of Agent.btz and used by Turla, first identified in 2007 and has undergone substantial development since.

entities.name: REGIN
entities.description: Regin is a malware platform that has targeted victims in various industries, including telecom, government, and financial institutions, with timestamps dating back to 2003.

entities.name: BOOTRASH
entities.description: BOOTRASH is a Bootkit targeting Windows operating systems, used by threat actors in the financial sector.

entities.name: UROBUROS
entities.description: Uroburos is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool used by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the Turla toolset, designed to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide.

various industries, including telecom, government, and financial institutions, with timestamps dating back to 2003.</data>      <data key="d2">cf86360a07b56c2024c70b568b2a5441</data>    </node>    <node id="BOOTRASH">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">BOOTRASH is a Bootkit targeting Windows operating systems, used by threat actors in the financial sector.</data>      <data key="d2">cf86360a07b56c2024c70b568b2a5441</data>    </node>    <node id="UROBUROS">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Uroburos is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool used by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the Turla toolset, designed to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide.</data>      <data key="d2">cf86360a07b56c2024c70b568b2a5441</data>    </node>    <node id="TURNA">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">cf86360a07b56c2024c70b568b2a5441</data>    </node>
