chunk:
There are 7 software using the attack technique called Disk Structure Wipe. Their names are as follows:
* RawDisk
* Shamoon
* HermeticWiper
* WhisperGate
* KillDisk
* StoneDrill
* CaddyWiper

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: RawDisk
Software description: [RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364) is a legitimate commercial driver from the EldoS Corporation that is used for interacting with files, disks, and partitions. The driver allows for direct modification of data on a local computer's hard drive. In some cases, the tool can enact these raw disk modifications from user-mode processes, circumventing Windows operating system security features.(Citation: EldoS RawDisk ITpro)(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Shamoon
Software description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) is wiper malware that was first used by an Iranian group known as the "Cutting Sword of Justice" in 2012. Other versions known as Shamoon 2 and Shamoon 3 were observed in 2016 and 2018. [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has also been seen leveraging [RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364) and Filerase to carry out data wiping tasks. Analysis has linked [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) with [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) based on multiple shared artifacts and coding patterns.(Citation: Cylera Kwampirs 2022) The term Shamoon is sometimes used to refer to the group using the malware as well as the malware itself.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HermeticWiper
Software description: [HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) is a data wiper that has been used since at least early 2022, primarily against Ukraine with additional activity observed in Latvia and Lithuania. Some sectors targeted include government, financial, defense, aviation, and IT services.(Citation: SentinelOne Hermetic Wiper February 2022)(Citation: Symantec Ukraine Wipers February 2022)(Citation: Crowdstrike DriveSlayer February 2022)(Citation: ESET Hermetic Wiper February 2022)(Citation: Qualys Hermetic Wiper March 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WhisperGate
Software description: [WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689) is a multi-stage wiper designed to look like ransomware that has been used against multiple government, non-profit, and information technology organizations in Ukraine since at least January 2022.(Citation: Cybereason WhisperGate February 2022)(Citation: Unit 42 WhisperGate January 2022)(Citation: Microsoft WhisperGate January 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KillDisk
Software description: [KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) is a disk-wiping tool designed to overwrite files with random data to render the OS unbootable. It was first observed as a component of [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) malware during cyber attacks against Ukraine in 2015. [KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) has since evolved into stand-alone malware used by a variety of threat actors against additional targets in Europe and Latin America; in 2016 a ransomware component was also incorporated into some [KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) variants.(Citation: KillDisk Ransomware)(Citation: ESEST Black Energy Jan 2016)(Citation: Trend Micro KillDisk 1)(Citation: Trend Micro KillDisk 2)
Platforms: Linux, Windows

Software name: StoneDrill
Software description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) is wiper malware discovered in destructive campaigns against both Middle Eastern and European targets in association with [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064).(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CaddyWiper
Software description: [CaddyWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0693) is a destructive data wiper that has been used in attacks against organizations in Ukraine since at least March 2022.(Citation: ESET CaddyWiper March 2022)(Citation: Cisco CaddyWiper March 2022)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 6 software using the attack technique called Permission Groups Discovery. Their names are as follows:
* ShimRatReporter
* IcedID
* Carbon
* TrickBot
* MURKYTOP
* Siloscape

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: ShimRatReporter
Software description: [ShimRatReporter](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0445) is a tool used by suspected Chinese adversary [Mofang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0103) to automatically conduct initial discovery. The details from this discovery are used to customize follow-on payloads (such as [ShimRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0444)) as well as set up faux infrastructure which mimics the adversary's targets. [ShimRatReporter](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0445) has been used in campaigns targeting multiple countries and sectors including government, military, critical infrastructure, automobile, and weapons development.(Citation: FOX-IT May 2016 Mofang)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: IcedID
Software description: [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) is a modular banking malware designed to steal financial information that has been observed in the wild since at least 2017.  [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483)  has been downloaded by [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) in multiple campaigns.(Citation: IBM IcedID November 2017)(Citation: Juniper IcedID June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Carbon
Software description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) is a sophisticated, second-stage backdoor and framework that can be used to steal sensitive information from victims. [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) has been selectively used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) to target government and foreign affairs-related organizations in Central Asia.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)(Citation: Securelist Turla Oct 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TrickBot
Software description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) is a Trojan spyware program written in C++ that first emerged in September 2016 as a possible successor to [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024). [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) was developed and initially used by [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) for targeting banking sites in North America, Australia, and throughout Europe; it has since been used against all sectors worldwide as part of "big game hunting" ransomware campaigns.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)(Citation: IBM TrickBot Nov 2016)(Citation: CrowdStrike Wizard Spider October 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MURKYTOP
Software description: [MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) is a reconnaissance tool used by [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065). (Citation: FireEye Periscope March 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Siloscape
Software description: [Siloscape](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0623) is malware that targets Kubernetes clusters through Windows containers. [Siloscape](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0623) was first observed in March 2021.(Citation: Unit 42 Siloscape Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Containers

entities.name: SHIMRATREPORTER
entities.description: ShimRatReporter is a tool used by the suspected Chinese adversary Mofang to conduct initial discovery and customize follow-on payloads, targeting multiple sectors including government and military.

entities.name: ICEDID
entities.description: IcedID is a modular banking malware designed to steal financial information, observed in the wild since at least 2017, and has been downloaded by Emotet in multiple campaigns.

entities.name: CARBON
entities.description: Carbon is a sophisticated backdoor and framework used to steal sensitive information, selectively used by Turla to target government and foreign affairs-related organizations in Central Asia.

entities.name: TRICKBOT
entities.description: TrickBot is a Trojan spyware program that emerged in 2016, developed by Wizard Spider for targeting banking sites and used in ransomware campaigns worldwide.

entities.name: MURKYTOP
entities.description: MURKYTOP is a reconnaissance tool used by the group Leviathan.

entities.name: SILOSCAPE
entities.description: Siloscape is malware that targets Kubernetes clusters through Windows containers, first observed in March 2021.

entities.name: MOFANG
entities.description: Mofang is a suspected Chinese adversary group associated with cyber operations, including the use of ShimRatReporter.

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a malware strain known for distributing other malware, including IcedID, and has been active in various campaigns.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber espionage group known for sophisticated attacks, including the use of Carbon to target sensitive organizations.

entities.name: WIZARD SPIDER
entities.description: Wizard Spider is a cybercriminal group known for developing TrickBot and engaging in ransomware attacks.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform on which various malware, including ShimRatReporter, IcedID, Carbon, TrickBot, MURKYTOP, and Siloscape operate.

entities.name: WINDOWS CONTAINERS
entities.description: Windows Containers are a virtualization technology used to run applications in isolated environments, targeted by Siloscape.

chunk: There are 10 software using the attack technique called Domain Groups. Their names are as follows: * Net * BloodHound * SILENTTRINITY * AdFind * Brute Ratel C4 * CrackMapExec * dsquery * Kwampirs * GRIFFON * Cobalt Strike The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows: Software name: *** Software description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates. Software name: Net Software description: The [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) utility is a component of the Windows operating system. It is used in command-line operations for control of users, groups, services, and network connections. (Citation: Microsoft Net Utility) [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) has a great deal of functionality, (Citation: Savill 1999) much of which is useful for an adversary, such as gathering system and network information for Discovery, moving laterally through [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002) using net use commands, and interacting with services. The net1.exe utility is executed for certain functionality when net.exe is run and can be used directly in commands such as net1 user. Platforms: Windows Software name: BloodHound Software description: [BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521) is an Active Directory (AD) reconnaissance tool that can reveal hidden relationships and identify attack paths within an AD environment.(Citation: GitHub Bloodhound)(Citation: CrowdStrike BloodHound April 2018)(Citation: FoxIT Wocao December 2019) Platforms: Windows Software name: SILENTTRINITY Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019) Platforms: Windows Software name: AdFind Software description: [AdFind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0552) is a free command-line query tool that can be used for gathering information from Active Directory.(Citation: Red Canary Hospital Thwarted Ryuk October 2020)(Citation: FireEye FIN6 Apr 2019)(Citation: FireEye Ryuk and Trickbot January 2019) Platforms: Windows Software name: Brute Ratel C4 Software description: [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool that first appeared in December 2020. [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was specifically designed to avoid detection by endpoint detection and response (EDR) and antivirus (AV) capabilities, and deploys agents called badgers to enable arbitrary command execution for lateral movement, privilege escalation, and persistence. In September 2022, a cracked version of [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was leaked in the cybercriminal underground, leading to its use by threat actors.(Citation: Dark Vortex Brute Ratel C4)(Citation: Palo Alto Brute Ratel July 2022)(Citation: MDSec Brute Ratel August 2022)(Citation: SANS Brute Ratel October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Black Basta October 2022) Platforms: Windows Software name: CrackMapExec Software description: [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488), or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python and designed for penetration testing against networks. [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) collects Active Directory information to conduct lateral movement through targeted networks.(Citation: CME Github September 2018) Platforms: Windows Software name: dsquery Software description: [dsquery](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0105) is a command-line utility that can be used to query Active Directory for information from a system within a domain. (Citation: TechNet Dsquery) It is typically installed only on Windows Server versions but can be installed on non-server variants through the Microsoft-provided Remote Server Administration Tools bundle. Platforms: Windows Software name: Kwampirs Software description: [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) is a backdoor Trojan used by [Orangeworm](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0071). [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) has been found on machines which had software installed for the use and control of high-tech imaging devices such as X-Ray and MRI machines.(Citation: Symantec Orangeworm April 2018) [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) has multiple technical overlaps with [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) based on reverse engineering analysis.(Citation: Cylera Kwamp

entities.name: NET
entities.description: Net is a command-line utility component of the Windows operating system used for control of users, groups, services, and network connections, often utilized for adversarial purposes in system and network information gathering.

entities.name: BLOODHOUND
entities.description: BloodHound is an Active Directory reconnaissance tool that reveals hidden relationships and identifies attack paths within an Active Directory environment.

entities.name: SILENTTRINITY
entities.description: SILENTTRINITY is an open-source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python, used in cyber campaigns against government agencies.

entities.name: ADFIND
entities.description: AdFind is a free command-line query tool for gathering information from Active Directory.

entities.name: BRUTE RATEL C4
entities.description: Brute Ratel C4 is a commercial red-teaming tool designed to avoid detection by security systems, enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

entities.name: CRACKMAPEXEC
entities.description: CrackMapExec is a post-exploitation tool developed for penetration testing against networks, designed to collect Active Directory information.

entities.name: DSQUERY
entities.description: dsquery is a command-line utility for querying Active Directory information from a system within a domain, typically installed on Windows Server versions.

entities.name: KWAMPIRS
entities.description: Kwampirs is a backdoor Trojan used by Orangeworm, found on machines controlling high-tech imaging devices like X-Ray and MRI machines.

entities.name: GRIFFON
entities.description: GRIFFON is a software tool used for various cyber operations, including reconnaissance and exploitation in network environments.

Software name: GRIFFON
Software description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) is a JavaScript backdoor used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046). (Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cobalt Strike
Software description: [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called PubPrn. Their names are as follows:
* Execution Prevention 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems, including suspicious processes, files, and API calls.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation methods are strategies designed to reduce or eliminate the impact of attack techniques like PubPrn.

There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Keychain. Their names are as follows:
* Password Policies 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies is a mitigation method that involves setting and enforcing secure password policies for accounts to protect against attacks like Keychain.

There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called LSASS Driver. Their names are as follows:
* Privileged Process Integrity 
* Credential Access Protection 
* Restrict Library Loading 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Process Integrity
Mitigation method description: Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.

Mitigation method name: Credential Access Protection
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.

Mitigation method name: Restrict Library Loading
Mitigation method description: Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.

entities.name: CREDENTIAL ACCESS PROTECTION
entities.description: Credential Access Protection is a mitigation method that prevents successful credential access by adversaries, including blocking forms of credential dumping.

entities.name: RESTRICT LIBRARY LOADING
entities.description: Restrict Library Loading is a mitigation method that prevents the abuse of library loading mechanisms to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate mechanisms and investigating vulnerable software.

entities.name: LSASS DRIVER
entities.description: LSASS Driver is an attack technique that targets the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service, which is responsible for enforcing security policies on Windows systems.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Keylogging. Their names are as follows:
* Empire
* PowerSploit
* Imminent Monitor
* QuasarRAT
* PoshC2
* PcShare
* Pupy
* Remcos
* SILENTTRINITY
* AsyncRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Imminent Monitor
Software description: [Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434) was a commodity remote access tool (RAT) offered for sale from 2012 until 2019, when an operation was conducted to take down the Imminent Monitor infrastructure. Various cracked versions and variations of this RAT are still in circulation.(Citation: Imminent Unit42 Dec2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: PcShare
Software description: [PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) is an open source remote access tool that has been modified and used by Chinese threat actors, most notably during the FunnyDream campaign since late 2018.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)(Citation: GitHub PcShare 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Remcos
Software description: [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) is a closed-source tool that is marketed as a remote control and surveillance software by a company called Breaking Security. [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) has been observed being used in malware campaigns.(Citation: Riskiq Remcos Jan 2018)(Citation: Talos Remcos Aug 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remcos
Software description: [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) is a closed-source tool that is marketed as a remote control and surveillance software by a company called Breaking Security. [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) has been observed being used in malware campaigns.(Citation: Riskiq Remcos Jan 2018)(Citation: Talos Remcos Aug 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CSPY Downloader
Software description: [CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527) is a tool designed to evade analysis and download additional payloads used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094).(Citation: Cybereason Kimsuky November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: UACMe
Software description: [UACMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0116) is an open source assessment tool that contains many methods for bypassing Windows User Account Control on multiple versions of the operating system. (Citation: Github UACMe)
Platforms: None

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: BlackEnergy
Software description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) is a malware toolkit that has been used by both criminal and APT actors. It dates back to at least 2007 and was originally designed to create botnets for use in conducting Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, but its use has evolved to support various plug-ins. It is well known for being used during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008, as well as in targeting Ukrainian institutions. Variants include BlackEnergy 2 and BlackEnergy 3. (Citation: F-Secure BlackEnergy 2014)
Platforms: Windows

* Antivirus/Antimalware 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Mitigation method description: Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Software name: ***
Software description: ***

These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LaZagne
Software description: [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system. It has modules for Windows, Linux, and OSX, but is mainly focused on Windows systems. [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub LaZagne Dec 2018)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Lslsass
Software description: [Lslsass](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0121) is a publicly-available tool that can dump active logon session password hashes from the lsass process. (Citation: Mandiant APT1)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Impacket
Software description: [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Windows Credential Editor
Software description: [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) is a password dumping tool. (Citation: Amplia WCE)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mimikatz
Software description: [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, along with many other features that make it useful for testing the security of networks. (Citation: Deply Mimikatz) (Citation: Adsecurity Mimikatz Guide)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShell

entities.name: SILENTTRINITY
entities.description: SILENTTRINITY is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. It was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.

entities.name: LAZAGNE
entities.description: LaZagne is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system, mainly focused on Windows systems but has modules for Linux and OSX.

entities.name: LSLSASS
entities.description: Lslsass is a publicly-available tool that can dump active logon session password hashes from the lsass process.

entities.name: IMPACKET
entities.description: Impacket is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols, containing tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, and more.

entities.name: PUPY
entities.description: Pupy is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation tool written in Python, capable of being generated as a payload in various formats.

entities.name: POSHC2
entities.description: PoshC2 is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework, primarily focused on Windows implantation but also contains components for Linux/macOS.

entities.name: WINDOWS CREDENTIAL EDITOR
entities.description: Windows Credential Editor is a password dumping tool used for extracting credentials from Windows systems.

entities.name: MIKATKAZ
entities.description: Mimikatz is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, useful for testing network security.

entities.name: EMPIRE
entities.description: Empire is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework, primarily written in Python with post-exploitation agents in PowerShell and Python.

entities.name: POWERSPOILT
entities.description: PowerSploit is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of PowerShell modules and scripts for penetration testing tasks.

chunk:
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: POWERSPOILT
entities.description: PowerSploit is an open-source offensive security framework that includes PowerShell modules and scripts for penetration testing tasks such as code execution, persistence, and exfiltration.

entities.name: POWERSHELL
entities.description: PowerShell is a task automation framework that includes a command-line shell and associated scripting language, used in conjunction with PowerSploit.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is the operating system platform on which PowerSploit operates.

entities.name: GITHUB
entities.description: GitHub is a platform where PowerSploit's source code is hosted and available for public access.

entities.name: POWERSHELLMAGAZINE
entities.description: PowerShellMagazine is a publication that has cited PowerSploit in its articles.

entities.name: POWERSPLOIT DOCUMENTATION
entities.description: PowerSploit Documentation refers to the official documentation that provides details on how to use PowerSploit.

entities.name: CODE EXECUTION
entities.description: Code execution refers to the process of running a program or script, which is a key function of PowerSploit's capabilities.

entities.name: PERSISTENCE
entities.description: Persistence is a technique used to maintain access to a system even after a reboot or other interruptions, which is one of the tasks PowerSploit can perform.

entities.name: BYPASSING ANTI-VIRUS
entities.description: Bypassing anti-virus refers to methods used to evade detection by security software, a capability included in PowerSploit's functionalities.

entities.name: RECON
entities.description: Reconnaissance (recon) is the initial phase of penetration testing where information is gathered about the target system or network.

entities.name: EXFILTRATION
entities.description: Exfiltration is the unauthorized transfer of data from a computer or network, which PowerSploit can facilitate during penetration testing.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Service Stop. Their names are as follows:
* Clop
* LookBack
* Meteor
* WannaCry
* Royal
* Diavol
* Avaddon
* Olympic Destroyer
* Cheerscrypt
* Prestige

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Clop
Software description: [Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) is a ransomware family that was first observed in February 2019 and has been used against retail, transportation and logistics, education, manufacturing, engineering, automotive, energy, financial, aerospace, telecommunications, professional and legal services, healthcare, and high tech industries. [Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) is a variant of the CryptoMix ransomware.(Citation: Mcafee Clop Aug 2019)(Citation: Cybereason Clop Dec 2020)(Citation: Unit42 Clop April 2021) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LookBack
Software description: [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582) is a remote access trojan written in C++ that was used against at least three US utility companies in July 2019. The TALONITE activity group has been observed using [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582).(Citation: Proofpoint LookBack Malware Aug 2019)(Citation: Dragos TALONITE)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Meteor
Software description: [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is a wiper that was used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, the Ministry of Roads, and Urban Development systems, in July 2021. [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is likely a newer version of similar wipers called Stardust and Comet that were reportedly used by a group called "Indra" since at least 2019 against private companies in Syria.(Citation: Check Point Meteor Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WannaCry
Software description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) is ransomware that was first seen in a global attack during May 2017, which affected more than 150 countries. It contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploit EternalBlue.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: US-CERT WannaCry 2017)(Citation: Washington Post WannaCry 2017)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Royal
Software description: [Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) is ransomware that first appeared in early 2022;  a version that also targets ESXi servers was later observed in February 2023. [Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) employs partial encryption and multiple threads to evade detection and speed encryption. [Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) has been used in attacks against multiple industries worldwide--including critical infrastructure. Security researchers have identified similarities in the encryption routines and TTPs used in [Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) and [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) attacks and noted a possible connection between their operators.(Citation: Microsoft Royal ransomware November 2022)(Citation: Cybereason Royal December 2022)(Citation: Kroll Royal Deep Dive February 2023)(Citation: Trend Micro Royal Linux ESXi February 2023)(Citation: CISA Royal AA23-061A March 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Diavol
Software description: [Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) is a ransomware variant first observed in June 2021 that is capable of prioritizing file types to encrypt based on a pre-configured list of extensions defined by the attacker.  The [Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) Ransomware-as-a Service (RaaS) program is managed by [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) and it has been observed being deployed by [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534).(Citation: Fortinet Diavol July 2021)(Citation: FBI Flash Diavol January 2022)(Citation: DFIR Diavol Ransomware December 2021)(Citation: Microsoft Ransomware as a Service)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Avaddon

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Olympic Destroyer
Software description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) against the 2018 Winter Olympics, held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The main purpose of the malware was to render infected computer systems inoperable. The malware leverages various native Windows utilities and API calls to carry out its destructive tasks. [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) has worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network in order to maximize its destructive impact.(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018)(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Unit 74455 October 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cheerscrypt
Software description: [Cheerscrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1096) is a ransomware that was developed by [Cinnamon Tempest](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1021) and has been used in attacks against ESXi and Windows environments since at least 2022. [Cheerscrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1096) was derived from the leaked [Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638) source code and has infrastructure overlaps with deployments of Night Sky ransomware, which was also derived from [Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638).(Citation: Sygnia Emperor Dragonfly October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Cheerscrypt May 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Prestige
Software description: [Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) ransomware has been used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) since at least March 2022, including against transportation and related logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland in October 2022.(Citation: Microsoft Prestige ransomware October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Encrypted/Encoded File. Their names are as follows:
* PcShare
* Sliver
* IronNetInjector
* DEADEYE
* Torisma
* OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
* USBStealer
* Emissary
* Kessel
* Raindrop

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: PcShare
Software description: [PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) is an open source remote access tool that has been modified and used by Chinese threat actors, most notably during the FunnyDream campaign since late 2018.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)(Citation: GitHub PcShare 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Sliver
Software description: [Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) is an open source, cross-platform, red team command and control framework written in Golang.(Citation: Bishop Fox Sliver Framework August 2019)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: IronNetInjector
Software description: [IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) is a [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolchain that utilizes scripts from the open-source IronPython implementation of Python with a .NET injector to drop one or more payloads including [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126).(Citation: Unit 42 IronNetInjector February 2021 )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DEADEYE
Software description: [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) is a malware launcher that has been used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) since at least May 2021. [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) has variants that can either embed a payload inside a compiled binary (DEADEYE.EMBED) or append it to the end of a file (DEADEYE.APPEND).(Citation: Mandiant APT41)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Torisma
Software description: [Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678) is a second stage implant designed for specialized monitoring that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). [Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678) was discovered during an investigation into the 2020 Operation North Star campaign that targeted the defense sector.(Citation: McAfee Lazarus Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Software description: [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) is a macOS backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First discovered in 2015, [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has continued to make improvements using a plugin architecture to extend capabilities, specifically using `.dylib` files. [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) can also determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: Unit42 OceanLotus 2017)(Citation: TrendMicro MacOS April 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro MacOS Backdoor November 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: USBStealer
Software description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) is malware that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least 2005 to extract information from air-gapped networks. It does not have the capability to communicate over the Internet and has been used in conjunction with [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045). (Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014) (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Emissary
Software description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) is a Trojan that has been used by [Lotus Blossom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0030). It shares code with [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081), with both Trojans being part of a malware group referred to as LStudio. (Citation: Lotus Blossom Dec 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Kessel
Software description: [Kessel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0487) is an advanced version of OpenSSH which acts as a custom backdoor, mainly acting to steal credentials and function as a bot. [Kessel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0487) has been active since its C2 domain began resolving in August 2018.(Citation: ESET ForSSHe December 2018)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Raindrop
Software description: [Raindrop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0565) is a loader used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) that was discovered on some victim machines during investigations related to the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024). It was discovered in January 2021 and was

ESET ForSSHe December 2018)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Raindrop
Software description: [Raindrop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0565) is a loader used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) that was discovered on some victim machines during investigations related to the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024). It was discovered in January 2021 and was likely used since at least May 2020.(Citation: Symantec RAINDROP January 2021)(Citation: Microsoft Deep Dive Solorigate January 2021)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: RAINDROP
entities.description: Raindrop is a software loader used by APT29, discovered during investigations related to the SolarWinds Compromise, likely in use since at least May 2020.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group known for its sophisticated attacks, including the SolarWinds Compromise.

entities.name: SOLARWINDS COMPROMISE
entities.description: The SolarWinds Compromise refers to a significant cyber attack that affected numerous organizations globally, discovered in December 2020.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system widely used in servers and personal computers.

entities.name: WINDOWS

entities.name: MAY 2020
entities.description: May 2020 is the earliest date suggested for when Raindrop was likely in use.

entities.name: SYMANTEC
entities.description: Symantec is a cybersecurity company that provides security software and services, including reports on cyber threats.

entities.name: MICROSOFT
entities.description: Microsoft is a technology company known for its software products, including Windows and security solutions.

There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Windows Management Instrumentation. Their names are as follows:
* Privileged Account Management 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* User Account Management 
* Execution Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks the execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Audio Capture. Their names are as follows:
* PowerSploit
* Pupy
* Imminent Monitor
* Remcos
* Flame
* ROKRAT
* Bandook
* VERMIN
* TajMahal
* EvilGrab

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Imminent Monitor
Software description: [Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434) was a commodity remote access tool (RAT) offered for sale from 2012 until 2019, when an operation was conducted to take down the Imminent Monitor infrastructure. Various cracked versions and variations of this RAT are still in circulation.(Citation: Imminent Unit42 Dec2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remcos
Software description: [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) is a closed-source tool that is marketed as a remote control and surveillance software by a company called Breaking Security. [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) has been observed being used in malware campaigns.(Citation: Riskiq Remcos Jan 2018)(Citation: Talos Remcos Aug 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Flame
Software description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) is a sophisticated toolkit that has been used to collect information since at least 2010, largely targeting Middle East countries. (Citation: Kaspersky Flame)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ROKRAT
Software description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) is a cloud-based remote access tool (RAT) used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) to target victims in South Korea. [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used ROKRAT during several campaigns from 2016 through 2021.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: Talos Group123)(Citation: Volexity InkySquid RokRAT August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bandook
Software description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) is a commercially available RAT, written in Delphi and C++, that has been available since at least 2007. It has been used against government, financial, energy, healthcare, education, IT, and legal organizations in the US, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia. [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has been used by [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070), as well as in a separate campaign referred to as "Operation Manul".(Citation: EFF Manul Aug 2016)(Citation: Lookout Dark Caracal Jan 2018)(Citation: CheckPoint Bandook Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: VERMIN
Software description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is a remote access tool written in the Microsoft .NET framework. It is mostly composed of original code, but also has some open source code. (Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TajMahal
Software description: [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is a multifunctional spying framework that has been in use since at least 2014. [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is comprised of two separate packages, named Tokyo and Yokohama, and can deploy up to 80 plugins.(Citation: Kaspersky TajMahal April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EvilGrab
Software description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) is a malware family with common reconnaissance capabilities. It has been deployed by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) via malicious Microsoft Office documents as part of spearphishing campaigns. (Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper

entities.name: POWERSPOILT
entities.description: PowerSploit is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of PowerShell modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration.

entities.name: PUPY
entities.description: Pupy is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation tool written in Python, available on multiple platforms including Windows, Linux, macOS, and Android.

entities.name: IMMINENT MONITOR
entities.description: Imminent Monitor was a commodity remote access tool (RAT) offered for sale from 2012 until 2019, with various cracked versions still in circulation.

entities.name: REMOS
entities.description: Remcos is a closed-source remote control and surveillance software marketed by Breaking Security, observed in malware campaigns.

entities.name: FLAME
entities.description: Flame is a sophisticated toolkit used to collect information, largely targeting Middle East countries since at least 2010.

entities.name: ROKRAT
entities.description: ROKRAT is a cloud-based remote access tool (RAT) used by APT37 to target victims in South Korea, utilized in several campaigns from 2016 through 2021.

entities.name: BANDOOK
entities.description: Bandook is a commercially available RAT, written in Delphi and C++, used against various organizations in the US, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia since at least 2007.

entities.name: VERMIN
entities.description: VERMIN is a remote access tool written in the Microsoft .NET framework, composed of original and some open source code.

entities.name: TAJMAHAL
entities.description: TajMahal is a multifunctional spying framework in use since at least 2014, comprised of two packages, Tokyo and Yokohama, capable of deploying up to 80 plugins.

entities.name: EVILGRAB
entities.description: EvilGrab is a malware family with reconnaissance capabilities, deployed by menuPass via malicious Microsoft Office documents in spearphishing campaigns.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a cyber espionage group known for using ROKRAT in targeted attacks, particularly against South Korean entities.

There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Scheduled Task. Their names are as follows:
* Privileged Account Management 
* User Account Management 
* Audit 
* Operating System Configuration 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

chunk: There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Group Policy Discovery. Their names are as follows: The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: Group Policy Discovery Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather information on Group Policy settings to identify paths for privilege escalation, security measures applied within a domain, and to discover patterns in domain objects that can be manipulated or used to blend in the environment. Group Policy allows for centralized management of user and computer settings in Active Directory (AD). Group policy objects (GPOs) are containers for group policy settings made up of files stored within a predictable network path `\\SYSVOL\\Policies\`.(Citation: TechNet Group Policy Basics)(Citation: ADSecurity GPO Persistence 2016) Adversaries may use commands such as gpresult or various publicly available PowerShell functions, such as Get-DomainGPO and Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup, to gather information on Group Policy settings.(Citation: Microsoft gpresult)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire) Adversaries may use this information to shape follow-on behaviors, including determining potential attack paths within the target network as well as opportunities to manipulate Group Policy settings (i.e. [Domain or Tenant Policy Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1484)) for their benefit. Platforms: Windows

entities.name: GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY
entities.description: Group Policy Discovery is an attack technique used by adversaries to gather information on Group Policy settings for privilege escalation and security measures within a domain.

entities.name: ACTIVE DIRECTORY
entities.description: Active Directory is a directory service developed by Microsoft for Windows domain networks, allowing centralized management of user and computer settings.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the Group Policy Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: PRIVILEGE ESCALATION
entities.description: Privilege Escalation is a technique used by adversaries to gain elevated access to resources that are normally protected from the user.

entities.name: DOMAIN OBJECTS
entities.description: Domain Objects are entities within Active Directory that can be manipulated or used by adversaries to blend into the environment.

entities.name: GPOS
entities.description: Group Policy Objects (GPOs) are containers for Group Policy settings that are stored within a predictable network path in Active Directory.

entities.name: GPRESULT
entities.description: gpresult is a command-line tool used to display the Resultant Set of Policy (RSoP) information for a user or computer in a Windows environment.

entities.name: POWERSHELL
entities.description: PowerShell is a task automation framework from Microsoft, consisting of a command-line shell and associated scripting language, which can be used to gather information on Group Policy settings.

entities.name: GET-DOMAINGPO
entities.description: Get-DomainGPO is a PowerShell function that retrieves information about Group Policy Objects in a domain.

entities.name: GET-DOMAINGPOLOCALGROUP
entities.description: Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup is a PowerShell function that retrieves information about local Group Policy settings in a domain.

attr.type="string" />  <key id="d0" for="node" attr.name="type" attr.type="string" />  <graph edgedefault="undirected">    <node id="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Group Policy Discovery is an attack technique used by adversaries to gather information on Group Policy settings for privilege escalation and security measures within a domain.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="ACTIVE DIRECTORY">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Active Directory is a directory service developed by Microsoft for Windows domain networks, allowing centralized management of user and computer settings.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="WINDOWS">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">Windows is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the Group Policy Discovery attack technique.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="PRIVILEGE ESCALATION">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Privilege Escalation is a technique used by adversaries to gain elevated access to resources that are normally protected from the user.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="DOMAIN OBJECTS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Domain Objects are entities within Active Directory that can be manipulated or used by adversaries to blend into the environment.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="GPOS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Group Policy Objects (GPOs) are containers for Group Policy settings that are stored within a predictable network path in Active Directory.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="GPRESULT">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">gpresult is a command-line tool used to display the Resultant Set of Policy (RSoP) information for a user or computer in a Windows environment.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="POWERSHELL">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">PowerShell is a task automation framework from Microsoft, consisting of a command-line shell and associated scripting language, which can be used to gather information on Group Policy settings.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="GET-DOMAINGPO">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Get-DomainGPO is a PowerShell function that retrieves information about Group Policy Objects in a domain.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="GET-DOMAINGPOLOCALGROUP">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup is a PowerShell function that retrieves information about local Group Policy settings in a domain.</data>      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <node id="GROUP POLICY SETTINGS">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </node>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="ACTIVE DIRECTORY">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Group Policy Discovery is a technique that involves gathering information from Active Directory settings</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="WINDOWS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Group Policy Discovery is an attack technique that targets the Windows operating system</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="GROUP POLICY SETTINGS">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">Group Policy Discovery involves gathering information on Group Policy Settings to identify potential attack paths</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="PRIVILEGE ESCALATION">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Group Policy Discovery can lead to Privilege Escalation by identifying paths for gaining elevated access</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="DOMAIN OBJECTS">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">Group Policy Discovery helps adversaries discover Domain Objects that can be manipulated</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="GPRESULT">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">The gpresult command can be used as part of the Group Policy Discovery technique to gather information</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="POWERSHELL">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">PowerShell can be utilized to execute commands like Get-DomainGPO and Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup for Group Policy Discovery</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="GET-DOMAINGPO">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Get-DomainGPO is a PowerShell function that aids in the Group Policy Discovery process</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY" target="GET-DOMAINGPOLOCALGROUP">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup is a PowerShell function that assists in gathering information for Group Policy Discovery</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>    <edge source="ACTIVE DIRECTORY" target="GPOS">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">GPOs are stored within Active Directory and are used to manage Group Policy settings</data>      <data key="d5">3a7b3b73472ceeb7a90eef762633ab72</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Email Collection. Their names are as follows:
* Multi-factor Authentication 
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Audit 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Multi-factor Authentication
Mitigation method description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION
entities.description: Multi-factor Authentication is a security method that requires two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system, enhancing security beyond just a username and password.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a method that protects sensitive data by using strong encryption techniques to ensure confidentiality and integrity.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a process of performing checks or scans on systems to identify potential weaknesses, including permissions and insecure configurations.
