chunk: kernel data structures for Linux based systems managing virtual memory. For each process, the `/proc//maps` file shows how memory is mapped within the process’s virtual address space. And `/proc//mem`, exposed for debugging purposes, provides access to the process’s virtual address space.(Citation: Picus Labs Proc cump 2022)(Citation: baeldung Linux proc map 2022) When executing with root privileges, adversaries can search these memory locations for all processes on a system that contain patterns indicative of credentials. Adversaries may use regex patterns, such as grep -E "^[0-9a-f-]* r" /proc/"$pid"/maps | cut -d' ' -f 1, to look for fixed strings in memory structures or cached hashes.(Citation: atomic-red proc file system) When running without privileged access, processes can still view their own virtual memory locations. Some services or programs may save credentials in clear text inside the process’s memory.(Citation: MimiPenguin GitHub May 2017)(Citation: Polop Linux PrivEsc Gitbook) If running as or with the permissions of a web browser, a process can search the `/maps` & `/mem` locations for common website credential patterns (that can also be used to find adjacent memory within the same structure) in which hashes or cleartext credentials may be located. Platforms: Linux Attack technique name: NTDS Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to access or create a copy of the Active Directory domain database in order to steal credential information, as well as obtain other information about domain members such as devices, users, and access rights. By default, the NTDS file (NTDS.dit) is located in %SystemRoot%\NTDS\Ntds.dit of a domain controller.(Citation: Wikipedia Active Directory) In addition to looking for NTDS files on active Domain Controllers, adversaries may search for backups that contain the same or similar information.(Citation: Metcalf 2015) The following tools and techniques can be used to enumerate the NTDS file and the contents of the entire Active Directory hashes. * Volume Shadow Copy * secretsdump.py * Using the in-built Windows tool, ntdsutil.exe * Invoke-NinjaCopy Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Cached Domain Credentials Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to access cached domain credentials used to allow authentication to occur in the event a domain controller is unavailable.(Citation: Microsoft - Cached Creds) On Windows Vista and newer, the hash format is DCC2 (Domain Cached Credentials version 2) hash, also known as MS-Cache v2 hash.(Citation: PassLib mscache) The number of default cached credentials varies and can be altered per system. This hash does not allow pass-the-hash style attacks, and instead requires [Password Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002) to recover the plaintext password.(Citation: ired mscache) On Linux systems, Active Directory credentials can be accessed through caches maintained by software like System Security Services Daemon (SSSD) or Quest Authentication Services (formerly VAS). Cached credential hashes are typically located at `/var/lib/sss/db/cache.[domain].ldb` for SSSD or `/var/opt/quest/vas/authcache/vas_auth.vdb` for Quest. Adversaries can use utilities, such as `tdbdump`, on these database files to dump the cached hashes and use [Password Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002) to obtain the plaintext password.(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix) With SYSTEM or sudo access, the tools/utilities such as [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075), and secretsdump.py for Windows or Linikatz for Linux can be used to extract the cached credentials.(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix) Note: Cached credentials for Windows Vista are derived using PBKDF2.(Citation: PassLib mscache) Platforms: Windows, Linux Attack technique name: LSASS Memory Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory. These credential materials can be harvested by an administrative user or SYSTEM and used to conduct [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) using [Use Alternate Authentication Material](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550). As well as in-memory techniques, the LSASS process memory can be dumped from the target host and analyzed on a local system. For example, on the target host use procdump: * procdump -ma lsass.exe lsass_dump Locally, mimikatz can be run using: * sekurlsa::Minidump lsassdump.dmp * sekurlsa::logonPasswords Built-in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used: * rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID lsass.dmp full(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks Against Government Sector) Similar to [Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process

chunk: -in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used: * rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID lsass.dmp full(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks Against Government Sector) Similar to [Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process exit mechanism can be abused to create a memory dump of `lsass.exe` through Windows Error Reporting (`WerFault.exe`).(Citation: Deep Instinct LSASS) Windows Security Support Provider (SSP) DLLs are loaded into LSASS process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014) The following SSPs can be used to access credentials: * Msv: Interactive logons, batch logons, and service logons are done through the MSV authentication package. * Wdigest: The Digest Authentication protocol is designed for use with Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and Simple Authentication Security Layer (SASL) exchanges.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection) * Kerberos: Preferred for mutual client-server domain authentication in Windows 2000 and later. * CredSSP: Provides SSO and Network Level Authentication for Remote Desktop Services.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to dump the contents of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow to enable offline password cracking. Most modern Linux operating systems use a combination of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow to store user account information including password hashes in /etc/shadow. By default, /etc/shadow is only readable by the root user.(Citation: Linux Password and Shadow File Formats) The Linux utility, unshadow, can be used to combine the two files in a format suited for password cracking utilities such as John the Ripper:(Citation: nixCraft - John the Ripper) # /usr/bin/unshadow /etc/passwd /etc/shadow > /tmp/crack.password.db Platforms: Linux

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called DNS. Their names are as follows:
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering, configuring software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: NETWORK APPLIANCES
entities.description: Network appliances are devices used to filter network traffic, ensuring secure data transmission by managing ingress and egress traffic.

entities.name: INTRUSION DETECTION SIGNATURES
entities.description: Intrusion detection signatures are patterns used to identify and block malicious traffic at network boundaries.

Software name: HOPLIGHT

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remsec
Software description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is a modular backdoor that has been used by [Strider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0041) and appears to have been designed primarily for espionage purposes. Many of its modules are written in Lua. (Citation: Symantec Strider Blog)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay. Their names are as follows:
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Network Segmentation 
* Filter Network Traffic 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning is an attack technique that exploits vulnerabilities in network protocols to intercept and manipulate network traffic.

entities.name: SMB RELAY
entities.description: SMB Relay is an attack technique that allows an attacker to intercept and relay authentication requests to gain unauthorized access to network resources.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: This mitigation method involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: This mitigation method uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: This mitigation method involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems and prevent access to sensitive information.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: This mitigation method uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering to enhance security.

entities.name: NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Network traffic refers to the data that is transmitted over a network, which can be subject to various attack techniques including LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called System Owner/User Discovery. Their names are as follows:
* NBTscan
* Koadic
* Pupy
* AsyncRAT
* QuasarRAT
* BloodHound
* SILENTTRINITY
* Empire
* Trojan.Karagany
* PoetRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: NBTscan
Software description: [NBTscan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0590) is an open source tool that has been used by state groups to conduct internal reconnaissance within a compromised network.(Citation: Debian nbtscan Nov 2019)(Citation: SecTools nbtscan June 2003)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)(Citation: FireEye APT39 Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: AsyncRAT
Software description: [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087) is an open-source remote access tool originally available through the NYANxCAT Github repository that has been used in malicious campaigns.(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Cisco Operation Layover September 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BloodHound
Software description: [BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521) is an Active Directory (AD) reconnaissance tool that can reveal hidden relationships and identify attack paths within an AD environment.(Citation: GitHub Bloodhound)(Citation: CrowdStrike BloodHound April 2018)(Citation: FoxIT Wocao December 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Trojan.Karagany
Software description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) is a modular remote access tool used for recon and linked to [Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035). The source code for [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) originated from Dream Loader malware which was leaked in 2010 and sold on underground forums. (Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)(Citation: Secureworks Karagany July 2019)(Citation: Drag

entities.description: Trojan.Karagany is a modular remote access tool used for reconnaissance, linked to the Dragonfly group, with its source code originating from leaked Dream Loader malware.

(Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)(Citation: Secureworks Karagany July 2019)(Citation: Dragos DYMALLOY )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PoetRAT
Software description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that was first identified in April 2020. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has been used in multiple campaigns against the private and public sectors in Azerbaijan, including ICS and SCADA systems in the energy sector. The STIBNITE activity group has been observed using the malware. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) derived its name from references in the code to poet William Shakespeare. (Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)(Citation: Talos PoetRAT October 2020)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: DRAGONFLY
entities.description: Dragonfly is a cyber threat group linked to various malware attacks, including the use of the PoetRAT and Trojan.Karagany tools.

entities.name: TROJAN.KARAGANY
entities.description: Trojan.Karagany is a modular remote access tool used for reconnaissance, linked to the Dragonfly group, and originated from Dream Loader malware.

entities.name: DREAM LOADER
entities.description: Dream Loader is a type of malware from which the source code for Trojan.Karagany was derived, leaked in 2010 and sold on underground forums.

entities.name: POETRAT
entities.description: PoetRAT is a remote access trojan first identified in April 2020, used in campaigns against sectors in Azerbaijan, including ICS and SCADA systems in the energy sector.

entities.name: STIBNITE
entities.description: STIBNITE is an activity group observed using the PoetRAT malware in various cyber campaigns.

entities.name: AZERBAIJAN
entities.description: Azerbaijan is a country where PoetRAT has been used in multiple cyber campaigns against both private and public sectors.

entities.name: SYMANTEC
entities.description: Symantec is a cybersecurity company known for its antivirus products and threat intelligence, including insights on the Dragonfly group.

entities.name: DRAGOS
entities.description: Dragos is a cybersecurity firm specializing in industrial control systems (ICS) security and has reported on various malware threats, including PoetRAT.

entities.name: ICS
entities.description: Industrial Control Systems (ICS) are critical systems used in various industries, including energy, which have been targeted by cyber threats like PoetRAT.

entities.name: SCADA
entities.description: Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems are used for industrial control and have been targeted in cyber campaigns involving PoetRAT.)<|COMPLETE|>

There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Sharepoint. Their names are as follows:
* Audit 
* User Account Management 
* User Training 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method aimed at training users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by adversaries to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

entities.description: Sharepoint is a platform that can be targeted by attack techniques, necessitating the implementation of various mitigation methods to enhance security.

chunk:
There are 2 software using the attack technique called Cloud Instance Metadata API. Their names are as follows:
* Peirates
* Hildegard

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Peirates
Software description: [Peirates](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0683) is a post-exploitation Kubernetes exploitation framework with a focus on gathering service account tokens for lateral movement and privilege escalation. The tool is written in GoLang and publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: Peirates GitHub)
Platforms: Containers

Software name: Hildegard
Software description: [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations. The malware was first observed in January 2021. The TeamTNT activity group is believed to be behind [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601). (Citation: Unit 42 Hildegard Malware)
Platforms: Linux, Containers, IaaS

entities.name: PEIRATES
entities.description: Peirates is a post-exploitation Kubernetes exploitation framework designed for gathering service account tokens for lateral movement and privilege escalation, written in GoLang and available on GitHub.

entities.name: HILDEGARD
entities.description: Hildegard is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations, first observed in January 2021 and attributed to the TeamTNT activity group.

entities.name: TEAMTNT
entities.description: TeamTNT is a cybercriminal group known for its activities involving cryptocurrency mining and targeting cloud environments, including Kubernetes.

entities.name: GO
entities.description: Go is a programming language developed by Google, known for its simplicity and efficiency, often used in cloud and server-side applications.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Service Stop. Their names are as follows:
* Network Segmentation 
* User Account Management 
* Restrict Registry Permissions 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: Network Segmentation is a mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources, using physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to sensitive systems and information.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts.

entities.name: RESTRICT REGISTRY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict Registry Permissions is a mitigation method that involves restricting the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves restricting access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: SERVICE STOP
entities.description: Service Stop is an attack technique that aims to disrupt services by stopping critical processes or services in a system.

chunk:
There are 9 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Create or Modify System Process. Their names are as follows:
* User Account Management 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Limit Software Installation 
* Privileged Account Management 
* Operating System Configuration 
* Audit 
* Software Configuration 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Code Signing 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems, including suspicious processes, files, and API calls.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a mitigation method that blocks users or groups from installing unapproved software to maintain system integrity.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root accounts.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that involves making configuration changes related to the operating system to harden the system against various attack techniques.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: SOFTWARE CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Software Configuration is a mitigation method that implements configuration changes to software to mitigate security risks associated with its operation.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that restricts access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: CODE SIGNING
entities.description: Code Signing is a mitigation method that enforces binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.name: CREATE OR MODIFY SYSTEM PROCESS
entities.description: Create or Modify System Process is an attack technique that can be mitigated through various methods, including those listed in the document.

chunk:
There are 3 software using the attack technique called Security Support Provider. Their names are as follows:
* Mimikatz
* Empire
* PowerSploit

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Mimikatz
Software description: [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, along with many other features that make it useful for testing the security of networks. (Citation: Deply Mimikatz) (Citation: Adsecurity Mimikatz Guide)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Net Crawler
Software description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) is an intranet worm capable of extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading to systems on a network over SMB by brute forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a copy of [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 2 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Data from Configuration Repository. Their names are as follows:
* Network Device Configuration Dump
* SNMP (MIB Dump)

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Data from Configuration Repository
Attack technique description: Adversaries may collect data related to managed devices from configuration repositories. Configuration repositories are used by management systems in order to configure, manage, and control data on remote systems. Configuration repositories may also facilitate remote access and administration of devices.

Adversaries may target these repositories in order to collect large quantities of sensitive system administration data. Data from configuration repositories may be exposed by various protocols and software and can store a wide variety of data, much of which may align with adversary Discovery objectives.(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: US-CERT TA17-156A SNMP Abuse 2017)
Platforms: Network

Attack technique name: Network Device Configuration Dump
Attack technique description: Adversaries may access network configuration files to collect sensitive data about the device and the network. The network configuration is a file containing parameters that determine the operation of the device. The device typically stores an in-memory copy of the configuration while operating, and a separate configuration on non-volatile storage to load after device reset. Adversaries can inspect the configuration files to reveal information about the target network and its layout, the network device and its software, or identifying legitimate accounts and credentials for later use.

Adversaries can use common management tools and protocols, such as Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) and Smart Install (SMI), to access network configuration files.(Citation: US-CERT TA18-106A Network Infrastructure Devices 2018)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks) These tools may be used to query specific data from a configuration repository or configure the device to export the configuration for later analysis. 
Platforms: Network

Attack technique name: SNMP (MIB Dump)
Attack technique description: Adversaries may target the Management Information Base (MIB) to collect and/or mine valuable information in a network managed using Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

The MIB is a configuration repository that stores variable information accessible via SNMP in the form of object identifiers (OID). Each OID identifies a variable that can be read or set and permits active management tasks, such as configuration changes, through remote modification of these variables. SNMP can give administrators great insight in their systems, such as, system information, description of hardware, physical location, and software packages(Citation: SANS Information Security Reading Room Securing SNMP Securing SNMP). The MIB may also contain device operational information, including running configuration, routing table, and interface details.

Adversaries may use SNMP queries to collect MIB content directly from SNMP-managed devices in order to collect network information that allows the adversary to build network maps and facilitate future targeted exploitation.(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks) 
Platforms: Network

entities.name: DATA FROM CONFIGURATION REPOSITORY
entities.description: Data from Configuration Repository is an attack technique where adversaries collect data related to managed devices from configuration repositories used by management systems to configure and control remote systems.

entities.name: NETWORK DEVICE CONFIGURATION DUMP
entities.description: Network Device Configuration Dump is an attack technique where adversaries access network configuration files to collect sensitive data about the device and the network.

entities.name: SNMP (MIB DUMP)
entities.description: SNMP (MIB Dump) is an attack technique where adversaries target the Management Information Base (MIB) to collect valuable information in a network managed using Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

entities.name: MANAGEMENT INFORMATION BASE (MIB)
entities.description: The Management Information Base (MIB) is a configuration repository that stores variable information accessible via SNMP, allowing for the management of network devices.

entities.name: SIMPLE NETWORK MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL (SNMP)
entities.description: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is a protocol used for managing devices on IP networks, allowing for the collection of data from network devices.

the network.</data>      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <node id="SNMP (MIB DUMP)">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">SNMP (MIB Dump) is an attack technique where adversaries target the Management Information Base (MIB) to collect valuable information in a network managed using Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).</data>      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <node id="MANAGEMENT INFORMATION BASE (MIB)">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">The Management Information Base (MIB) is a configuration repository that stores variable information accessible via SNMP, allowing for the management of network devices.</data>      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <node id="SIMPLE NETWORK MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL (SNMP)">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is a protocol used for managing devices on IP networks, allowing for the collection of data from network devices.</data>      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <node id="CONFIGURATION REPOSITORIES">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <edge source="DATA FROM CONFIGURATION REPOSITORY" target="NETWORK DEVICE CONFIGURATION DUMP">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques involve adversaries collecting sensitive data from network configurations and repositories</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DATA FROM CONFIGURATION REPOSITORY" target="SNMP (MIB DUMP)">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques involve adversaries targeting repositories to extract sensitive information</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DATA FROM CONFIGURATION REPOSITORY" target="CONFIGURATION REPOSITORIES">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">Configuration repositories are the target of the Data from Configuration Repository attack technique</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="NETWORK DEVICE CONFIGURATION DUMP" target="SNMP (MIB DUMP)">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques utilize network management protocols to access sensitive configuration data</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="NETWORK DEVICE CONFIGURATION DUMP" target="SIMPLE NETWORK MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL (SNMP)">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">SNMP can be used to access network configuration files as part of the Network Device Configuration Dump technique</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SNMP (MIB DUMP)" target="MANAGEMENT INFORMATION BASE (MIB)">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">The MIB is accessed through SNMP to collect valuable information about network devices</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SNMP (MIB DUMP)" target="SIMPLE NETWORK MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL (SNMP)">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">SNMP is the protocol used to access the MIB for collecting network information</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

There are 3 software using the attack technique called Proc Filesystem. Their names are as follows:
* LaZagne
* MimiPenguin
* PACEMAKER

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: LaZagne
Software description: [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system. It has modules for Windows, Linux, and OSX, but is mainly focused on Windows systems. [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub LaZagne Dec 2018)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: MimiPenguin
Software description: [MimiPenguin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0179) is a credential dumper, similar to [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), designed specifically for Linux platforms. (Citation: MimiPenguin GitHub May 2017)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: PACEMAKER
Software description: [PACEMAKER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1109) is a credential stealer that was used by [APT5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1023) as early as 2020 including activity against US Defense Industrial Base (DIB) companies.(Citation: Mandiant Pulse Secure Zero-Day April 2021)
Platforms: Network, Linux

There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Winlogon Helper DLL. Their names are as follows:
* Execution Prevention 
* User Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts.

entities.name: VBA STOMPING
entities.description: VBA Stomping is an attack technique that exploits vulnerabilities in software to execute malicious code.

entities.description: This mitigation method involves removing or denying access to unnecessary software to prevent potential abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: UNNECESSARY SOFTWARE
entities.description: Unnecessary software refers to programs that are not essential for operations and may pose security risks if left accessible.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Fileless Storage. Their names are as follows:
* DarkWatchman
* PolyglotDuke
* QakBot
* TYPEFRAME
* ComRAT
* ShadowPad
* Gelsemium
* Uroburos
* SysUpdate
* Exaramel for Windows

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: DarkWatchman
Software description: [DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.(Citation: Prevailion DarkWatchman 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PolyglotDuke
Software description: [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) is a downloader that has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2013. [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) has been used to drop [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051).(Citation: ESET Dukes October 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TYPEFRAME
Software description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) is a remote access tool that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). (Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ComRAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ShadowPad
Software description: [ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) is a modular backdoor that was first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017. The malware was originally thought to be exclusively used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096), but has since been observed to be used by various Chinese threat activity groups. (Citation: Recorded Future RedEcho Feb 2021)(Citation: Securelist ShadowPad Aug 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky ShadowPad Aug 2017) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Gelsemium
Software description: [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) is a modular malware comprised of a dropper (Gelsemine), a loader (Gelsenicine), and main (Gelsevirine) plug-ins written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) framework. [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has been used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014.(Citation: ESET Gelsemium June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Uroburos
Software description: [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool written in C that has been used by units within Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolset to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and can easily incorporate new or replacement components.(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
Platforms

entities.name: POLYGLOTDUKE
entities.description: PolyglotDuke is a downloader used by APT29 since at least 2013, capable of dropping MiniDuke, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: QAKBOT
entities.description: QakBot is a modular banking trojan used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007, evolving from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, and operates on Windows.

TYPEFRAME is a remote access tool used by the Lazarus Group and operates on Windows.
TYPEFRAME is a remote access tool that has been used by the Lazarus Group, operating on Windows.

entities.name: COMRAT
entities.description: ComRAT is a second stage implant suspected to be a descendant of Agent.btz, used by Turla, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: SHADOWPAD
entities.description: ShadowPad is a modular backdoor first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017, used by various Chinese threat activity groups, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: GELSEMIUM
entities.description: Gelsemium is a modular malware used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014, comprised of a dropper, loader, and main plug-ins, and operates on Windows.

entities.name: UROBUROS
entities.description: Uroburos is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool used by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the Turla toolset, designed to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide, and operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: Exaramel for Windows
Software description: [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343) is a backdoor used for targeting Windows systems. The Linux version is tracked separately under [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401).(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 2 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Disk Wipe. Their names are as follows:
* Disk Structure Wipe
* Disk Content Wipe

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Disk Wipe
Attack technique description: Adversaries may wipe or corrupt raw disk data on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. With direct write access to a disk, adversaries may attempt to overwrite portions of disk data. Adversaries may opt to wipe arbitrary portions of disk data and/or wipe disk structures like the master boot record (MBR). A complete wipe of all disk sectors may be attempted.

To maximize impact on the target organization in operations where network-wide availability interruption is the goal, malware used for wiping disks may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging additional techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)

On network devices, adversaries may wipe configuration files and other data from the device using [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands such as `erase`.(Citation: erase_cmd_cisco)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network

Attack technique name: Disk Structure Wipe
Attack technique description: Adversaries may corrupt or wipe the disk data structures on a hard drive necessary to boot a system; targeting specific critical systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. 

Adversaries may attempt to render the system unable to boot by overwriting critical data located in structures such as the master boot record (MBR) or partition table.(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018) The data contained in disk structures may include the initial executable code for loading an operating system or the location of the file system partitions on disk. If this information is not present, the computer will not be able to load an operating system during the boot process, leaving the computer unavailable. [Disk Structure Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/002) may be performed in isolation, or along with [Disk Content Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/001) if all sectors of a disk are wiped.

On a network devices, adversaries may reformat the file system using [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands such as `format`.(Citation: format_cmd_cisco)

To maximize impact on the target organization, malware designed for destroying disk structures may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging other techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network

Attack technique name: Disk Content Wipe
Attack technique description: Adversaries may erase the contents of storage devices on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources.

Adversaries may partially or completely overwrite the contents of a storage device rendering the data irrecoverable through the storage interface.(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster)(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)(Citation: DOJ Lazarus Sony 2018) Instead of wiping specific disk structures or files, adversaries with destructive intent may wipe arbitrary portions of disk content. To wipe disk content, adversaries may acquire direct access to the hard drive in order to overwrite arbitrarily sized portions of disk with random data.(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware) Adversaries have also been observed leveraging third-party drivers like [RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364) to directly access disk content.(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster)(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware) This behavior is distinct from [Data Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) because sections of the disk are erased instead of individual files.

To maximize impact on the target organization in operations where network-wide availability interruption is the goal, malware used for wiping disk content may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging additional techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network

entities.name: DISK STRUCTURE WIPE
entities.description: Disk Structure Wipe is an attack technique that corrupts or wipes the disk data structures on a hard drive necessary to boot a system, targeting critical systems to interrupt availability.

entities.name: DISK CONTENT WIPE
entities.description: Disk Content Wipe is an attack technique where adversaries erase the contents of storage devices to interrupt availability to system and network resources.

entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can be targeted by attack techniques such as Disk Wipe, Disk Structure Wipe, and Disk Content Wipe.

entities.name: NETWORK
entities.description: Network refers to the systems and devices that can be targeted by attack techniques such as Disk Wipe, Disk Structure Wipe, and Disk Content Wipe.

chunk:
There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Data from Removable Media. Their names are as follows:
* Data Loss Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Data Loss Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.(Citation: PurpleSec Data Loss Prevention)

entities.name: DATA LOSS PREVENTION
entities.description: Data Loss Prevention is a mitigation method that categorizes sensitive data, identifies formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restricts the exfiltration of sensitive data.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation methods are strategies or techniques employed to reduce the risk of data breaches and protect sensitive information.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Internet Connection Discovery. Their names are as follows:
* GoldFinder
* More_eggs
* Neoichor
* SUGARUSH
* NKAbuse
* QakBot
* QuietSieve
* SysUpdate
* DarkTortilla
* Woody RAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: GoldFinder
Software description: [GoldFinder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0597) is a custom HTTP tracer tool written in Go that logs the route a packet takes between a compromised network and a C2 server. It can be used to inform  threat actors of potential points of discovery or logging of their actions, including C2 related to other malware. [GoldFinder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0597) was discovered in early 2021 during an investigation into the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024) by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016).(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: More_eggs
Software description: [More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) is a JScript backdoor used by [Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) and [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037). Its name was given based on the variable "More_eggs" being present in its code. There are at least two different versions of the backdoor being used, version 2.0 and version 4.4. (Citation: Talos Cobalt Group July 2018)(Citation: Security Intelligence More Eggs Aug 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Neoichor
Software description: [Neoichor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0691) is C2 malware used by [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) since at least 2019; similar malware families used by the group include Leeson and Numbldea.(Citation: Microsoft NICKEL December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SUGARUSH
Software description: [SUGARUSH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1049) is a small custom backdoor that can establish a reverse shell over TCP to a hard coded C2 address. [SUGARUSH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1049) was first identified during analysis of UNC3890's [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010) campaign targeting Israeli companies, which began in late 2020.(Citation: Mandiant UNC3890 Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NKAbuse
Software description: [NKAbuse](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1107) is a Go-based, multi-platform malware abusing NKN (New Kind of Network) technology for data exchange between peers, functioning as a potent implant, and equipped with both flooder and backdoor capabilities.(Citation: NKAbuse BC)(Citation: NKAbuse SL)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuietSieve
Software description: [QuietSieve](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0686) is an information stealer that has been used by [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) since at least 2021.(Citation: Microsoft Actinium February 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: DarkTortilla
Software description: [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter that has been possibly active since at least August 2015. [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154), and Metasploit.(Citation: Secureworks

chunk:
5. [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154), and Metasploit.(Citation: Secureworks DarkTortilla Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Woody RAT
Software description:  [Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that has been used since at least August 2021 against Russian organizations.(Citation: MalwareBytes WoodyRAT Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Network Logon Script. Their names are as follows:
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: NETWORK LOGON SCRIPT
entities.description: Network Logon Script is an attack technique that can be mitigated through specific methods to enhance security.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting directory and file permissions to limit access.

entities.name: RESTRICT ACCESS
entities.description: Restrict access is a general term referring to the practice of limiting user permissions to enhance security, particularly in the context of file and directory permissions.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called NTFS File Attributes. Their names are as follows:
* esentutl
* Expand
* Regin
* Valak
* LoJax
* PowerDuke
* DEADEYE
* POWERSOURCE
* WastedLocker
* BitPaymer

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: esentutl
Software description: [esentutl](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0404) is a command-line tool that provides database utilities for the Windows Extensible Storage Engine.(Citation: Microsoft Esentutl)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Expand
Software description: [Expand](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0361) is a Windows utility used to expand one or more compressed CAB files.(Citation: Microsoft Expand Utility) It has been used by [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) to decompress a CAB file into executable content.(Citation: Palo Alto Networks BBSRAT)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Regin
Software description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) is a malware platform that has targeted victims in a range of industries, including telecom, government, and financial institutions. Some [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) timestamps date back to 2003. (Citation: Kaspersky Regin)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LoJax
Software description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) is a UEFI rootkit used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) to persist remote access software on targeted systems.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PowerDuke
Software description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) is a backdoor that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) in 2016. It has primarily been delivered through Microsoft Word or Excel attachments containing malicious macros. (Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DEADEYE
Software description: [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) is a malware launcher that has been used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) since at least May 2021. [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) has variants that can either embed a payload inside a compiled binary (DEADEYE.EMBED) or append it to the end of a file (DEADEYE.APPEND).(Citation: Mandiant APT41)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWERSOURCE
Software description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) is a PowerShell backdoor that is a heavily obfuscated and modified version of the publicly available tool DNS_TXT_Pwnage. It was observed in February 2017 in spearphishing campaigns against personnel involved with United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filings at various organizations. The malware was delivered when macros were enabled by the victim and a VBS script was dropped. (Citation: FireEye FIN7 March 2017) (Citation: Cisco DNSMessenger March 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WastedLocker
Software description: [WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) is a ransomware family attributed to [Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119) that has been used since at least May 2020. [WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) has been used against a broad variety of sectors, including manufacturing, information technology, and media.(Citation: Symantec WastedLocker June 2020)(Citation: NCC Group WastedLocker June 2020)(Citation: Sentinel Labs WastedLocker July 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BitPaymer
Software description: [BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) is a ransomware variant first observed in August 2017 targeting hospitals in the U.K. [BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) uses a unique encryption key, ransom note, and contact information for each operation. [BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) has several indicators suggesting overlap with the [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) malware and is often delivered via [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384).(Citation: Crowdstrike Indrik November 2018)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: WASTEDLOCKER

entities.name: BITPAYMER
entities.description: BitPaymer is a ransomware variant first observed in August 2017, targeting hospitals in the U.K. and often delivered via Dridex malware.

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called System Firmware. Their names are as follows:
* Boot Integrity 
* Update Software 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Boot Integrity
Mitigation method description: Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.

Mitigation method name: Update Software
Mitigation method description: Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods are strategies employed to reduce the risk of attacks, specifically in the context of System Firmware.

chunk:
There are 7 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle. Their names are as follows:
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Limit Access to Resource Over Network 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* User Training 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Network Segmentation 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation method description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

entities.name: ADVERSARY-IN-THE-MIDDLE
entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle is an attack technique that involves intercepting and potentially altering communication between two parties without their knowledge.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a mitigation method that protects sensitive information with strong encryption.

entities.name: LIMIT ACCESS TO RESOURCE OVER NETWORK
entities.description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network is a mitigation method that prevents access to file shares and remote systems, using mechanisms like network concentrators and RDP gateways.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a mitigation method that involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method that educates users about access or manipulation attempts to reduce risks from social engineering and spearphishing.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: Network Segmentation is a mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems and prevent access to sensitive information.

There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Modify Cloud Compute Infrastructure. Their names are as follows:
* User Account Management 
* Audit 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.
